description.narrative:
The main purpose of the project is to enhance emergency preparedness and crisis management capacities at the national and sub-national levels. A key element of this project is to strengthen the resilience at the municipal, governorate and central levels and among vulnerable communities to external crises and shocks through risk planning, management and financing, emergency preparedness systems and capacities. A study identifying the existing systems, capacities, gaps and needs will be undertaken under the directionof MOMA and in coordination with MOIto inform the design of the specific support that will be provided to the relevant institutions and vulnerable communities under this sub-component. Based on the study, the subcomponent could support the preparation and operationalization of emergency preparedness plans, training of communities and public officials, establishment of crisismanagement protocols and systems, and so forth.
While Jordan has already shown an impressive level of resilience in responding to the current refugee crisis, JESSRP is designed specifically to further strengthen existing mechanisms and institutions that have allowed highly affected communities cope so far, whether at the individual, community or institutional level.
Subcomponent 2B will seek to strengthen the institutional capacity and resilience of Government entities at the central, governorate and municipal level to better address the adverse impacts of external shocks and stresses. While the municipal grant seek to alleviate some of the more immediate stresses stemming from current increased pressure on local services, this subcomponent will take its point of departure from the fact that (i) this is neither the first nor likely the last refugee crisis experienced by Jordan; and (ii) this is a multifaceted crisis that requires drawing on expertise from many different sectors at all levels of Government.
A study will be carried out during the JESSRP Project implementation to analyze and assess the existing capacities, gaps and needs in the areas of emergency preparedness, risk planning and management and resource mobilization. The collection of timely and accurate information and the management information flows forms the foundation for relevant crisis response. Similarly, strategic communication has been identified as a key element in natural disaster settings as it helps build trust, credibility, and transparency by ensuring that the right messages are reaching all relevant stakeholders. Particular attention will therefore be given to this aspect of crisis management and its usefulness in efforts to build resilience related to man-made crises will be explored. The study will form the basis for the design of a capacity enhancing program that will target specialized support to different levels of government and identified communities. The study and ensuing support will be carried out under the directionof MOMA and in coordination with MOI.
The project will build the capacity of key Government agencies and vulnerable communities in emergency preparedness, and risk planning, management and financing. Information collated during the Assessment phase will support the institutional mapping and modeling exercise and a training gap analysis.
A detailed organizational assessment will be developed and undertaken that ranges from the institutional to local levels. The purpose of this activity is: to assess current municipalities' capacities for training, access to information and infrastructure for the critical DRR and DRM knowledge areas; to establish municipal capacity baselines and examine the potential effects of external opportunities and threats on capacity development initiative strengths and weaknesses; to identify the critical capacities needed by the project; to review the role of the private sector and non-governmental organizations with respect to DRR and DRM; to identify the various capacity development priorities of various stakeholders within the sector; and to review any existing system for information exchange between organizational institutional components.
A participatory stakeholder analysis exercise will take place during the 3 days workshop with a sample of informants. This process will allow a more detailed stakeholder profile of interests and responsibilities in DRR at both the macro- and micro-levels. This analysis will include perceptions of roles and responsibilities, especially by central and local government departments. Wherever significant differences in the stakeholder profile around the municipality of the selected cities are identified, this will also be documented. This will be important in guiding a more detailed assessment of capacities for action, generating a strategy for more integrated stakeholder participation in DRR and DRM, and will facilitate prioritization of future project work-planning in conjunction with parallel hazard and vulnerability assessment activities.
In order to develop a more detailed understanding of local level needs and priorities and how these are aligned with DRR and DRM, a questionnaire survey will be conducted. The primary purpose of the survey will be to evaluate the extent of public awareness, early warning and preparation for natural hazards, the perception of levels of service and support that can be provided by the state and other agencies, and also a personal awareness of fundamental rights in a disaster. For evaluation of this final ethical dimension, the Humanitarian Charter and the Sphere minimum standards for disaster response will be used as a reference tool.
The Project will entail developing a priority action plan listing key institutional development activities related to emergency preparedness and risk mitigation and management in consultation with other agencies/entities (especially MOMA, MOI, , MOPIC, Governorates and municipalities, civil society representatives), that can be implemented during the rest of lifetime of the JESSRP project as per the agreed timeline, ,as well as sharing information and carrying out strategic communication activities related to the subcomponent.
The Project will be jointly implemented in collaboration with a National Jordanian NGO ( Jordanian Humanitarian Resilience Society( JHRS), with UN-Habitat as lead Management. Within UN-Habitat the project will be supported from concerned headquarters' departments, namely the Urban Risk Reduction Unit at the Risk Reduction and Rehabilitation Branch, the UN-Habitat Office for Disaster Risk Reduction will provide the backstopping technical and training support as indicated in technical proposal.
The Ministry of Interior/Ministry of Municipal Affairs (PMU) will intervene in the planning, monitoring, implementation of the project, the respective Governorates and Municipalities, local NGOs, CBOs and government institutions, Academic organizations and professional networks will intervene in the implementation of the project , planning, and implementation, Vulnerable conflict affected families especially the most vulnerable: groups, youth and women groups /host communities will also be engaged in the implementation of the project.
